channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Join Our Merry Band of Perl Programmers
item.description: The role in our client's Belarus office offers a unique opportunity to join an established company in a new office. You’ll get in on the ground floor with the Belarus team. Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack, and a solid grounding in using Perl’s testing tools.

item.title: Smart Shopper = Smart Saver. Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Very well-known Austrian e-commerce brand looking for a Perl programmer whose love of saving money is matched only by their ability to deliver high-quality content and well-executed user information. Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: A New Adventure is only a Click Away. Perl Developer role in London
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dance, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: A Role that Makes Dollars (and Cents). Perl Developer Role in London
item.description: To be the best in their field, our client has gathered a world-class team with the skills and expertise to tailor content to different site aesthetics. Reaching over 349 million consumers worldwide is a big responsibility, and this engaged team is more than up to the challenge. If you are a senior Perl/JS programmer with a passion for finance and business, this could be the role for you!

item.title: Looking Boss! 100% remote Perl role within UK & EU
item.description: Our client is looking for a full-stack Perl developer who takes autonomy to a new level. 100% remote and open to candidates who are residents of United Kingdom, Switzerland, and the European Economic Area. Strong Perl is a must as is DBIx::Class experience and basic front-end skills / not scared of small amounts of JavaScript, HTML and very comfortable on Linux, ideally Debian.

item.title: Toronto Perl Mongers Online Meeting
item.description: Thursday, July 22, 2021

item.title: Berlin Perl Mongers
item.description: Wednesday, June 30, 2021

item.description:
Great modules released last week;

item.title: Conference in the Cloud! A Perl and Raku Conf
Create a lexical warning that can be turned on and off with the "warnings" pragma.
Weekly Challenge 116
item.description: Simon shared an interesting story about numbers. Thanks for sharing the story and solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 116: Square Sequence
item.description: Roger figured out an interesting output from one of the given example. Good catch.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 116
item.description: Luis' one-liner is the winner for me this week. Well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 116: numbers
item.description: Luca's verbose solution is so simple to follow. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 116: Number Sequence and Sum of Squares
item.description: Laurent's blog is always very special as there are plenty of ideas to explore. Please check out the Raku tricks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #116
item.description: James found the second task easier than than the first and he proved it with his solutions. Oops.

item.title: PWC116 - Sum of Squares
item.description: Flavio's commentary on Raku features in interesting. Once again, the Raku solution wins the race for me. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC116 - Number Sequence
item.description: I enjoyed Raku solution more as it reminds me how I started using Raku. Brilliant job.

item.title: Hip To Be Square: Perl Weekly Challenge #116
item.description: Dave's use of a substr hack recursively to solve the task is fun to read. Please do check it out.

item.title: Shhh… We’re Squaring Sequet Numbers
item.description: Colin 'sblog is always full of interesting ideas. I loved his task analysis. Keep it going.

item.title: Sequential Squares with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne's bonus solution is really nice and his workaround hack used in Perl solution is cool. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Evolving a Sequence with a Functional Genome: The Weekly Challenge 116
item.description: I love the use of genetics to solve the task. My favourite this week. I will revisit it later.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 116: Sum of Squares
item.description: For this task, Abigail split the task to make it more easy to understand. Cool attempt.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 116: Number Sequence
item.description: Abigail's solution was hard to follow initially, but after the second read it become obvious. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 116
item.description: Aaron's use of Raku's power makes the task look so simple. Incredible.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 116
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Number Sequence" and "Sum of Squares" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 117
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Missing Row" and "Find Possible Paths". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Slides from "Blogging Outside the Bubble" Perl talk
item.description: Mark's slides from a recent talk he gave at CiC 2021.

item.title: Moving Perl Mojolicious routes to their own module
item.description: Mark experimenting with Mojolicious routes. Nice work.

item.title: Visualization of perl development history
item.description: Kang-min shared a 10-year review of perl5.git.

item.title: EPAN - Exclusive Perl Archive Nook
item.description: Flavio's 10-year-old code is finally out in public.

item.title: use VERSION - but how?
item.description: Flavio sharing an interesting use of VERSION.

item.title: Mojolicious::Plugin::Authentication example
item.description: A practical use case showing the power of Mojolicious::Plugin::Authentication.

item.title: My TPRCiC 2021 review
item.description: A thorough review of the recently concluded virtual conference by Thibault.

item.title: Pre-order Learning Perl 8th Edition
item.description: brian d foy's latest work is ready for pre-order. Please grab your copy.

item.title: Proposed RFC for Corinna
item.description: Curtis' proposal for creating an RFC for Corinna. What do you think? Please share your suggestions.

item.title: #516 - Conference in the Cloud
item.description:
Hi there

The highlight of last week was the Conference in the Cloud. It gave us the opportunity to meet and greet Perl and Raku fans from across the globe. On top of that, we got loads of quality talks by experts. Before I talk about anything else, let me thank and congratulate all the organisers and volunteers for such a successful event. I am personally impressed with the video quality of the live and recorded talks.

For me, I find the timing little bit odd as I am in the UK. The day started at 6:30pm British Summer Time, which is not ideal. At the end of a full day at $work, there is hardly any energy left to attend the talks live. But the best part wasthat the recorded talks were available on YouTube immediately. I find it convenient, as I can watch at my own time. Also I can fast-forward if I want to.

Please find below my personal favourites in no particular order.

1. perlimports or "Where did that symbol come from?" by Olaf Alders

2. Local dev setup for a complex app using docker-compose by Thomas Klausner

3. Introduction to Perl Data Types by William N. Braswell, Jr.

4. Rummaging in the clOOset by Curtis Poe

5. Life after Perl (and Raku) by Peter Sergeant

6. What's new in Perl? by Ricardo Signes

7. Perl's Amazing Time Machine by Paul Evans

8. Valiant - Heroic validations for Moo and DBIC classes by John Napiorkowski

9. Our shared vision of Perl by Andrew Solomon

10. Cross-platform native GUIs: {trade,pay}offs, {integra,distribu}tion by Zaki Mughal

There are plenty more to watch later. You can find the complete list here.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter and please stay safe.
